newsitem.title: GERMANY: German prod. prices post 4th annual rise in April.
newsitem.headline: German prod. prices post 4th annual rise in April.

text.p: German producer prices rose in April after remaining flat in March, nudging up the year-on-year rate of producer inflation to a 16-month high, the Federal Statistics Office said on Friday.
Producer prices rose by 0.3 percent in April compared to the previous month, and were up by 0.9 percent compared to the same month a year earlier.
The year-on-year figure was the fourth successive rise after an 11-month run of falls that ended last December, and the biggest gain since December 1995, the data showed.

In western Germany, producer prices were up by 0.4 percent on a monthly basis, compared to a fall of 0.1 percent in March. The year-on-year rise was in line with the national figure at 0.9 percent, up from 0.6 percent in March.

In the formerly communist east, prices were up by 0.3 percent after a monthly fall of 0.1 percent in March. Compared to a year earlier, producer prices were up by 1.6 percent, just up from 1.5 percent in the previous month.

The Statistics Office said that the main price changes in April were a jump in the cost of mined products by 3.1 percent, and in iron and steel of 1.0 percent. Petroleum products, however, fell by 1.4 percent in price.
In the economically dominant west, corrugated cardboard prices rose by 8.0 percent, natural gas by 5.1 percent, roast coffee by 3.2 percent and fresh pork by 2.8 percent.
Prices fell for bitumen by 12 percent, liquefied gas by 10 percent and heavy heating oil by 3.2 percent.
